title: Bridal Forest
credits: As part of Random Studio for Boucheron
lede: As a member of the Experience Design team at Random Studio, I contributed to the creation of nature-themed digital intervention for Boucheron's flagship store in Ginza, Japan.

text.heading: Insight
text.text: Upon joining the project, our team was tasked to infuse emotional depth into the shopping experience at the brand's new flagship store, particularly focusing on elevating the purchase of a wedding ring into a memorable moment for customers.

text.heading: Idea
text.text: The Bridal Forest is an interactive installation that exists as a poetic blend of tradition and technology. Inspired by the Japanese Tanabata tradition, it offers couples a unique ritual as they choose their wedding rings.

The Wishing Tree invites couples to write their wishes, casting them onto a physical birch with a simple gesture – ‘tying the knot’, that forges a lasting memory of a couple obtaining their Boucheron wedding bands.

text.heading: End Result
text.text: This ritual offers a real-time interaction between the space and the people in it, but also invites customers to take home a tangible memory of their ring-buying experience. Scanning a QR code, they can download a digital version of their wish to keep forever.

A user journey and intuitive UI for the embedded screen were designed to make the experience simple yet surprising for various types of guests, with an option to choose from Japanese, English or Korean languages.

text.heading: Process
text.text: I played an integral role in every stage of the project, from initial research and ideation to concept development. I led the creation of user journeys, prototyping, testing, and finalizing UI designs ready for development. Throughout the process, we constructed a prototype tree within the studio lab, facilitating continuous testing and refinement of designs to ensure seamless integration of physical and digital components.
